lines.text: "A guy turns 35." That's really what's buggin' you, isn't it? That you're about to turn 35.
Maybe. Maybe. Or maybe I don't see what's fun about kissing a dead chicken's ass.
Well that's 'cause you haven't tried it.

Now see here, Mr. French! I'm trying to be reasonable about this! Now our, our, our Jaycee Chapter is almost bankrupt because of this meat show!... and if we don't break even we're going to have to cancel the Rodeo for the Retarded.
Santa Rosa is so beautiful. I mean, I thought the shopping mall in Anaheim was great until I saw yours. It's... a credit to the vision of your business community.
Are you all right, darling? Can I get you anything? A doctor? A Pepsi?

[Demonstrating how to pack a suitcase, as part of the talent portion of a beauty contest she's participating in]
Also, so your shampoo and cosmetics don't spill, put all your gooey things in a plastic bag. I call it my "Icky Bag."
pack your naughtiest nightie right on top, in case you need it in a hurry.
Jesus! Doesn't anything get you down?
Yeah, I get my apple cart upset sometimes. I just learned a long time ago to accept a little less from life, that's all.
I... I realize that you and I have gotten off to a rather shaky start. But things don't have to stay that way. What do you say?
Let's keep it shaky.
Isn't she lovely? Aren't they all lovely? Isn't everyone lovely?
Kick and Bend. Kick and Bend. No dear, if you kick and bend at the same time you're going to knock yourself out.

[Bob has just given Andy a rather "rehearsed"-sounding motivational talk - something that sounds like it came directly from the beauty pageant]
Bob, I've finally figured out what you are. You know what you are? A goddamned 'Young American Miss'!
Another evening of sarcasm and self-pity...
Doesn't anything ever get you down?
Yeah, I get my apple cart upset sometimes. I just learned a long time ago to accept a little less from life, that's all.

[continues]
Want to know who taught me this great lesson in life? Elizabeth Taylor.

[looks incredulous]
What?
I never bothered to tell you the story because I don't believe in negative stories, but, uh, one time I actually had a date with old Liz herself.
You're kidding.
Huh-uh. Do you remember when I went off to junior college in Los Angeles? Well, I had a class with a guy that was Liz Taylor's cousin. He fixed me up with her.
What was she like?
I never met her.
You just said...

No, I just said that I had a "date" with her. I never said that she kept it. You should've seen all the preparations I made. I went out and got the best flowers that I could find, and a great table at the world-famous Cocoanut Grove restaurant. And then she never showed up. That was the weekend that she ran off and married the hotel guy.
I'm sorry.
Oh, you don't have to be sorry. Just that now I'm married to Roberta, and I'm happy about it. Even though she is... a little less than Elizabeth Taylor.

[pauses to reflect]
God, Elizabeth Taylor was beautiful.

[Addressing the beauty contestants before their big dance number]
Now listen. Just listen. In about two minutes, you're gonna' go out there and be professional dancers. Your job is to make the audience happy. Now, I know that a lot of you are scared and don't think you can do it. But I've been watching you all very carefully, and I know that you can.

[continues]
Now I'd like you to think about a 17-year-old kid... who came to me when I was staging dances for the Mike Curb Congregation. She hadn't had a bit of experience, but she wanted to try so bad that we just had to let her. That was four years ago, and now that girl is one of the Mike Curb lead dancers.

[the girls look mildly impressed]
Now, that may not seem like much to you ladies, but that girl... has a wooden foot. Now go out there and dance with your two *good* feet!

[Having overheard his story about the girl with the wooden foot]
That was really a beautiful story. Listen, I have a syndicated radio show heard in four states. I'm always looking for inspirational youth stories. Do you mind if I use that?
Be my guest... But it's total bullshit.

[looking at Brenda's book of beauty pageant applicants]
Wow, any real lookers this year?
Oh, you men...
What do you mean, "us men"? You women are checking each other out a lot more than any man I ever saw. You're always the first ones to sneak a look at the centerfold of "Playboy."
That's not true!

You know something, Dad? I know I sort of put down the pageant the last couple of years. But after reading these applications, I can see why you want to help these girls. They seem very, uh... worthwhile.
one day, you find yourself being interested in all sorts of new things.
Yeah!
You are tops.
I won Miss Teenage Complexion.
I don't think I've heard of that one.
It was sponsored by this horny old dermatologist in Orange County. He rented a room at the Disneyland Hotel... got 16 girls in bathing suits and he had his own beauty contest.
You're kidding me! Well, didn't you get mad?
No. I won $200 and had a wart removed.
You see, old Phil's just mad because his auto repair shop isn't doing as well as my mortuary. We sell more caskets than he does gaskets.
[With jokes like that, not hard to see why]

[referring to Ray Brandy, the band leader]
I don't like that music man. He's mean to the Young American Misses. It's a depressing thing to see one person being mean to another person. I need a drink.

[Unlocks a Pepsi machine in the corridor, fetches a bottle of booze stashed inside, takes a drink]
For those who think young.

[referring to Maria, aka Miss Salinas, Mexican-American contestant]
God, how can you stand being her roommate?
It's all right. She spends most of her time in the kitchen, making guacamole dip.
What happened?
One of the girls fainted. She'll be all right.
Did she trip? Trip over a nail or something we could be sued for?
No, and I'll tell her how concerned you were.

[watching the Young Miss contestants perform a big dance number on stage]
You know something? You did a hell of a job.

[cynically]
I took a bunch of nice high-school kids, and turned them into Vegas showgirls.
I'm getting a reputation for being a drunk, aren't I?
No, you certainly are not.
It's true.
No, it's not true.
sliding.
